marketNews.title: BEI Chairman Iman Rachman to discuss market confidence measures
marketNews.content: BEI Chief Executive Iman Rachman said on Friday (28/2) that the exchange will soon discuss with market participants—including securities firms, asset managers, and listed companies—to create policies that improve investor confidence, without specifying when the meeting will take place. His statement came as the IDX fell to 6,271 on Friday, the lowest level since September 2021. BEI Director Jeffrey Hendrik added that one of the topics to be discussed is the continuation of derivative products that could be negative for investors, including short selling and intraday short selling, which had previously been scheduled for release in 2Q25.

marketNews.title: US President Donald Trump announces tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China
marketNews.content: US President Donald Trump said on Thursday (27/2) that an import tariff of 25% for Canada and Mexico will be implemented on March 4, 2025, together with an additional 10% tariff for China. Previously, China had been subject to a 10% import tariff by the US since the beginning of the month. The implementation of tariffs for Canada and Mexico was delayed for a month due to negotiations aimed at strengthening border security to meet US demands for combating high levels of drug trafficking from those neighboring countries.

marketNews.title: Bank Indonesia says central bank intervened in FX market as rupiah falls
marketNews.content: Bank Indonesia's Head of Monetary Management and Securities Assets Edi Susianto said today (Friday 28/2) that the central bank intervened in the foreign exchange market following the rupiah's depreciation to its worst level against the US dollar since April 2020. At the start of trading, the rupiah fell 0.7% to 16,578 per US dollar and the IDX dropped about 3% as US tariffs on Canada and Mexico were set to take effect next week.

marketNews.title: Fenwei Energy says Chinese coal buyers may renegotiate contracts due to new coal price reference
marketNews.content: Consulting firm Fenwei Energy Information Service Co. said on Thursday (27/2) that several Chinese companies might cancel or renegotiate long‑term contracts with Indonesian coal exporters following the implementation of the Coal Price Benchmark (HBA) as the export price reference from 1 March 2025. The China Coal Transportation and Distribution Association also noted that Indonesian coal purchases by Chinese buyers could decline if the HBA raises export prices significantly. The HBA price for February 2025 was set at USD 124.24 per ton, higher than the average Newcastle Australia coal futures price of USD 105 per ton for the same month. Reuters reported that the government still allows exporters to use prices stipulated in existing long‑term contracts, but expects adjustments where permissible.

marketNews.title: National Medium-Term Development Plan targets 20% middle class by 2029
marketNews.content: The National Medium-Term Development Plan (RPJMN) for 2025‑2029 aims for the middle‑class share of Indonesia's population to reach 20% by 2029 (up from 17.13% in 2024), still below the pre‑pandemic level of 21.45%. The plan notes that low purchasing power, reflected in deflation of government‑controlled price components and volatile prices, is a key driver of the decline. To increase the middle‑class share, the document calls for broader, higher‑quality job creation, especially in productive sectors such as manufacturing and high‑tech, and for informal sector employment to be boosted through farmer regeneration programs and an improved investment climate.

marketNews.title: BPK expert says audit of Coretax system underway
marketNews.content: Ahmad Adib Susilo, an expert at the Audit Board of Indonesia (BPK), said on Thursday (27/2) that the board is conducting an audit of the Coretax tax administration system, with the audit results likely to be released together with the 2024 audit report. The Coretax system, valued at 1.3 trillion rupiah, has been difficult for users to access since its launch on 31 December 2024, prompting the DPR and the Directorate General of Taxes to agree this month that tax reporting must continue using the old system.

tickerNews.title: BBRI 1M25: Net Profit -58% YoY, Provision Expenses Projected to Decrease
tickerNews.content: Bank Rakyat Indonesia (BBRI) recorded net profit (bank only) of 2 trillion rupiah in January 2025, down 58% YoY and 58% MoM, mainly due to: 1) provision expenses (credit cost) swelling to 5.6 trillion rupiah (vs Jan 2024: 2 trillion rupiah, Dec 2024: 1.2 trillion rupiah); and 2) Net Interest Margin (NIM) falling to 6.15% (vs Jan 2024: 6.63%, Dec 2024: 6.94%). Earlier, BBRI management in an FY24 earnings call mid‑month said there could be a one‑off adjustment from modification loss and front‑loading provisions affecting NIM and credit cost in 1H25, without giving specific numbers. Although a NIM decline and provision surge were expected, the market was surprised by the actual performance, causing BBRI shares to drop 7.4% today, Friday (28/2). In today's call, management explained that of the total 5.6 trillion rupiah provision expense (bank only) booked in January 2025, about 2 trillion rupiah is systematic provision (overall credit portfolio assessment). Approximately 3.5 trillion rupiah is additional management overlay linked to potential risk from the restructuring of Kupedes micro‑segment credit. Management said the overlay may appear in coming months but in smaller amounts, so provision expenses are projected to decline. BBRI confirmed that guidance for credit costs of about 300‑320 basis points consolidated for FY25 already incorporates the management overlay recorded in January 2025. Even though provision expenses are projected to fall, achieving the 300‑320 bps credit cost guidance for 2025 will depend heavily on key assumptions: 1) consolidated loan and financing growth of about 7‑9% YoY; and 2) completion of the Kupedes credit restructuring. Therefore, BBRI does not rule out the possibility of a consolidated net profit decline this year. Although credit performance and NIM remain low early in the year, BBRI expects credit growth and liquidity conditions to improve in 2Q25. Management also said dividend discussions for FY2024 point to a dividend payout ratio (DPR) around 85%, higher than the 80% DPR in FY2023. With an 85% DPR, the final dividend could be 204 rupiah per share, implying a dividend yield of 6.1% based on today's closing price of 3,360 rupiah. Future DPR policy will be a wait‑and‑see as BBRI operates under Danantara. Regarding Net Interest Income (NII) which fell 8% YoY, pressuring NIM in January 2025, management explained a reclassification of interest income in FY2024, including January 2024, where part of non‑interest fee income became interest income. Combined (NII + Non‑II), total BBRI revenue in January 2025 was essentially flat YoY (-0.1%) at 13 trillion rupiah. Key Takeaway: BBRI's performance recovery in the coming months will be crucial for investors, focusing on provision expenses, credit acceleration, and liquidity. Valuation: BBRI trades at 1.52x 1‑Year Forward P/BV, below the -2 standard deviation (1.62x) 10‑year historical average and the lowest since the Covid‑19 pandemic (1.32x). Risk: If performance recovery is slow, net profit FY25 consensus could be trimmed. Consensus projects FY25 net profit at a relatively flat 60.7 trillion rupiah (vs FY24: 60.2 trillion rupiah).

tickerNews.title: JPFA 2024: Net Profit +225% YoY, Exceeds Expectations
tickerNews.content: Japfa Comfeed Indonesia recorded net profit of 923 billion rupiah in 4Q24 (+50% QoQ, turning profitable from a loss in 4Q23). This made the 2024 net profit total 3 trillion rupiah (+225% YoY), surpassing expectations at 111%/108% of Stockbit/consensus estimates. The 4Q24 profit increase was driven by revenue growth (+7% QoQ, +8% YoY) and gross margin expansion to 23% (vs 3Q24: 19%, 4Q23: 12%) due to higher broiler prices (+10% QoQ) and DOC (+14% QoQ). In 2024, revenue grew to 9.7 trillion rupiah (+9% YoY) with gross margin rising to 20% (vs 2023: 15%).

tickerNews.title: BBNI January 2025 Net Profit +9.7% YoY
tickerNews.content: Bank Negara Indonesia recorded net profit (bank only) of 1.6 trillion rupiah in January 2025 (+9.7% YoY, +17% MoM), aligning with consensus expectations for 2025 consolidated performance, which forecast a +9.1% YoY growth. The result was driven by credit cost (CoC) easing to 0.82% in January 2025 (-32 bps YoY, -101 bps MoM), better than management's ±1% guidance and the lowest since January 2022. Pre‑Provision Operating Profit (PPOP) grew modestly +1.4% YoY, despite operating expenses rising +7.4% YoY and NIM falling to 3.71% (-6 bps YoY, -82 bps MoM), below management's 4‑4.2% guidance. Previously, BBNI indicated NIM would stay weak in 1H25 before strengthening in 2H25 due to tight liquidity. Credit growth reached +10.3% YoY in January 2025 (vs Jan 2024: +8.1% YoY, Dec 2024: +10.7% YoY), slightly above the consolidated guidance of +8‑10% YoY.

tickerNews.title: CMRY 4Q24 Net Profit 364 Billion Rupiah (+32% YoY)
tickerNews.content: Cisarua Mountain Dairy recorded net profit of 364 billion rupiah in 4Q24 (+32% YoY, +3% QoQ). This brought 2024 net profit to 1.5 trillion rupiah (+22% YoY), matching expectations at 102% of consensus. The 4Q24 profit was supported by revenue growth (+18% YoY, +8% QoQ) and gross margin expansion to 46% (+370 bps YoY, +50 bps QoQ) as raw material costs fell (-23% YoY, -27% QoQ). However, operating profit grew only +1% YoY (-40% QoQ) due to higher operating expenses (+43% YoY, +55% QoQ), mainly marketing (+70% YoY, +104% QoQ). Financial income contributed 86 billion rupiah and foreign exchange gains added 65 billion rupiah.

tickerNews.title: TAPG 4Q24 Net Profit 1.5 Trillion Rupiah (+131% QoQ, +198% YoY)
tickerNews.content: Triputra Agro Persada recorded net profit of 1.5 trillion rupiah in 4Q24 (+131% QoQ, +198% YoY). This resulted in 2024 net profit of 3.1 trillion rupiah (+94% YoY), exceeding expectations at 139% of consensus. The profit surge was driven by revenue growth (+58% QoQ, +50% YoY) and gross margin expansion to 50% (vs 3Q24: 35%, 4Q23: 31%) due to high CPO prices. In 2024, revenue rose to 9.7 trillion rupiah (+16% YoY) with gross margin expanding to 39% (vs 2023: 27%).

tickerNews.title: ASII invests $57 million in Halodoc, increasing stake to 31.34%
tickerNews.content: Astra International increased its ownership in health‑tech platform Halodoc through a transaction worth US$57 million early this year, as disclosed in the FY24 financial report. The transaction raised ASII's stake in Halodoc to 31.34%, with the company not detailing the pre‑transaction holding. With this investment, Astra's total investment in the health sector reached 5.2 trillion rupiah.

tickerNews.title: NINE shareholders sell shares, reducing holdings
tickerNews.content: Two shareholders of Techno9 Indonesia, Agatha Nindya and Merry Kandou, each sold 105.2 million and 57.6 million NINE shares at 19 rupiah per share between 25‑27 February 2025. The transactions valued at roughly 2 billion rupiah and 1.1 billion rupiah respectively. After the sales, Agatha's ownership fell from 10.64% to 5.76%, while Merry's fell from 2.67% to zero. The sales are part of Poh Group Pte. Ltd.'s plan to acquire 70% of NINE.

tickerNews.title: ESTA shareholder sells 308.3 million shares
tickerNews.content: Esta Multi Usaha shareholder Yeti Sopandi sold 308.3 million ESTA shares at 76 rupiah per share on 24‑25 February 2025, totaling about 23.4 billion rupiah. After the transaction, Yeti's ownership dropped from 16.01% to 3.3%.

tickerNews.title: SRIL to close March 1 2025, 10,665 layoffs
tickerNews.content: Textile company Sri Rejeki Isman (SRIL) will close on 1 March 2025, directly affecting 10,665 employees through layoffs. The closure follows a Semarang Commercial Court ruling declaring SRIL bankrupt after a lawsuit by PT Indo Bharat Rayon, despite a government promise to rescue the company. BEI Director I Gede Nyoman Yetna said the exchange is processing SRIL's delisting, but still needs to meet with SRIL management and market‑supporting professionals before a final decision.
